item.content:encoded: Hasan Eruslu - Internship at Theiss and NIST during summer 2018
item.excerpt:encoded: Hasan Eruslu - Internship at Theiss and NIST during summer 2018

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: heruslu
item.content:encoded:
Fourth year graduate student in Department of Mathematical Sciences, University of Delaware. I am currently in sustaining status which means I have completed all my course work, passed both of the preliminary tests and oral candidacy exam, and focusing on my thesis. I am a proud member of Team Pancho supervised by Dr. Francisco Sayas. Other members of our team are: Allan Hungria, Shukai Du and Hugo Diaz.

Interests

Numerical Analysis, Finite and Boundary Element Methods, Continuous and Discontinuous Galerkin Methods, Elliptic PDEs, Viscoelasticity, Scattering Theory, Image Segmentation, High Performance Computing, Software and Algorithm Development.

Programming Interests

Python, MATLAB, NumPy/SciPy, FEniCS/DOLFIN, Object Oriented Programming, OpenMP, MPI, GitHub.

Publications

  • F. Ecevit, and H. Eruslu. A Galerkin BEM for high-frequency scattering problems based on frequency-dependent changes of variables. IMA Journal of Numerical Analysis, 2018. DOI:10.1093/imanum/drx079

  • T.S. Brown, S. Du, H. Eruslu, and F.-J. Sayas. Analysis of models for viscoelastic wave propagation. Applied Mathematics and Nonlinear Sciences, 2018. DOI:10.21042/AMNS.2018.1.00006

More

Resume  --  LinkedIn    
  Photo: @Ocean City, MD

item.title: News
item.dc:creator: heruslu
item.content:encoded:
Internship at Theiss Research/NIST, 2018 Summer

I was a research assistant at Theiss Research under the supervision of Dr. Gunay Dogan at NIST for the summer. We developed a user friendly Python library for image segmentation problem. Our goal was resolving the surface of unknown objects in given 3D images. The tools we have implemented can be used in material science and medical imaging to obtain the numerical approximation of the surfaces and to help conducting numerical experiments. These experiments can then be run numerous times with no cost in order to simulate any desired effect in the material or the internal organ. Our work is still continuing and we will make the entire library available on GitHub.

Excellence in Graduate Teaching Award, 2018 May

I was humbled by 2017 Excellence in Graduate Teaching Award. It is a university-wide award which is given up to 2 graduate students each year. It also includes a financial gift of $1,500. I received my award at the University Faculty Senate Meeting on May 7, 2018. Below is a picture taken by Dean of College of Arts George Watson (Thank you Dean Watson! He was kind enough to tweet this great news as well). My award was also recognized at our Departmental Colloquium and Annual College of Arts and Science Celebrating Achievement and Success event. You can read more about this award, and check out UDaily and our department's kind comments about it. Acknowledgement: I want to thank everyone who nominated me for this award. I am grateful for all my teachers, mentors and advisors who helped me to build my current teaching philosophy. Special thanks for my first grade teacher Mrs. Tunc and my high school teachers from Manisa, Turkey for their extraordinary dedication!

Nonlocal School of Fractional Equations, 2017 August

I was at Nonlocal School of Fractional Equations. It was great to learn a little bit about the regularity and numerical methods for some fractional equations from Dr. Luis Caffarelli and Dr.Ricardo Nochetto. I was lucky enough to take a picture with Dr. Nochetto :)

Mid Atlantic Numerical Analysis Day, 2016 November

I attended to Mid Atlantic Numerical Analysis Day on Friday, November 11, 2016 at Temple University Department of Mathematics. Shukai and I presented a poster titled “Building a Computational Code for 3D Viscoelastic Wave Simulation” with co-authors Thomas Brown and Dr. Francisco Sayas. 

GEMS Summer Research, 2016 Summer

GEMS Research project. Worked on "Numerical simulations of viscoelastic waves" with Shukai Du and Guanyu Hou under the supervision of Dr. Francisco Sayas.

item.title: Math 242 Spring 2017 Tuesday Discussions

item.content:encoded:
Syllabus The discussion quiz schedule is on my syllabus. Please add them on your calendar. Every week, I will do some problems from the textbook. The discussion quizzes will be always similar to those problems. The list of the problems we did in class so far:
  • Week 1. Section 5.5: 13, 21, 25, 45.
  • Week 2. Section 4.4: 31, 33, 37, 44, 46.
  • Week 3. Section 6.1: 24,28; Section 6.2: 5,7,18. (Solution to 6.2.18)
  • Week 4. Section 6.3: 4,8,17; Section 6.5: 7.
  • Week 5. Section 7.1: 27; Section 7.2: 4, 25, 42; Section 7.3: 6.
  • Week 6. No class.
  • Week 7. Section 7.8: 11, 24, 31.
  • Week 8. Section 8.1: 11; Section 11.1: 30, 32, 35, 37, 42, 43, 44.
  • Week 9. Section 11.2: 29, 37; Section 11.3: 21; Section 11.4: 9, 31.
  • Week 10. Section 11.4: 9, 19, 31; Section 11.6: 4, 5, 13, 14, 26, 28.
  • Week 11. No class.
  • Week 12. Section 11.8: 5, 7, 8, 15; Section 11.9: 3, 5; Section 11.10: 12, 13, 37.
  • Week 13. Section 11.10: 40; Section 10.2: 13; Section 10.3: 30.
  • Week 14. Final Review.

item.title: Research
item.dc:creator: heruslu
item.content:encoded:
3D Boundary Element Methods

I am developing computational tools for boundary integral representation of solutions of wave problems. This also includes scattering on sound-soft obstacles. Currently I am improving our team's MATLAB library by including Laplace domain solutions of these problems using single and double layer potentials.  

Numerical Analysis of Viscoelastic Waves

The stress-strain relation of viscoelastic materials can be modeled using classical as well as fractional Zener models. We present properties of these models and the assumptions needed to investigate waves in viscoelastic media. Under external load and traction terms we study the stability and well-posedness of the viscoelastic wave problem in both the Laplace and time domains. We then examine the semidiscrete problem and analyze the error. We use our team's computational package to test our theoretical results on a problem with the fractional Zener model and create three dimensional simulation of the solution. Below is the result of one of our numerical simulations where the material is modeled by Fractional Zener model and the bottom of the solid is shaken but the rest of the boundary is free. The traveling viscoelastic waves from bottom to top as well as the dissipativity of the system are captured. Below is another simulation where we enforce displacement on the front face. Along y-axis the half of the rod is pure is elastic whereas the other half is modeled by viscoelastic Zener model. The change of color indicates stress. Fast and slow responses of elastic and viscoelastic parts can be seen. [video width="1280" height="642" mp4="https://sites.udel.edu/heruslu/files/2018/03/viscoelastic_waves_coupled_system_simulation-1ifd2cs.mp4"][/video]   The analysis of the time domain PDE is in our group paper: T.S. Brown, S. Du, H. Eruslu, and F.-J. Sayas. Analysis of models for viscoelastic wave propagation. Applied Mathematics and Nonlinear Sciences, 2018. DOI:10.21042/AMNS.2018.1.00006

item.title: Math 242 - Spring 2018
item.dc:creator: heruslu
item.content:encoded:
Spring 2018

Math 242 032D, 100D, 101D Office Hours for the week of May 14th: Monday 3:30-4:30 PM, Wednesday 9:30 - 10:30 AM; Thursday 9:30 - 10:30 AM @ Ewing 112 No office hours on these days: Thursday, February 15, 2018. Note: For the assessment schedule, see the syllabus below.
  • Syllabus
  • Week 1: Math 241 review. Section 5.5 Problems 13, 21, 25, 45.
  • Week 2: l'Hospital's rule. Section 4.4 Problems 23, 19, 24, 27, 43, 32, 33, 55.
  • Discussion Quiz 1 and solutions.
  • Week 3: 6.1 Area between curves, 6.2 Washer method, 6.3 Shell method. Went over some lecture quiz practice problems.
  • Week 4: Section 6.5 Average of a function. Section 7.1 Integration by Parts Problems 17, 23, 30.
  • Discussion Quiz 2 and solutions.
  • Week 5: Midterm 1 practice problems. 7.2 Integration of trigonometric functions Problems 1, 2, 11, 22, 27.
  • Week 6: 7.4 Integration using partial fractions Problems 1, 3, 5, 9, 47.
  • Week 7: Section 8.1 Arc length Problem 11. Section 11.1 Infinite Sequences Problems 27, 43.
    • Section 7.4 Integration using partial fractions - Class Note
  • Discussion Quiz 3a & 3b and solutions.
  • Week 8: Section 11.1 Sequences 26, 27, 43, 45. Section 11.2 Series 22, 25, 26, 29, 43.
  • Week 9: Section 7.8 Improper integrals Problems 6, 8, 9, 27. Section 11.3 Integral tests Problems 17, 19, 22.
  • Discussion Quiz 4 and solutions.
  • Week 10: Section 11.4 Comparison test Problems 7, 11, 20, 26. Section 11.5 Ratio and root tests Problems 18, 19, 25.
  • Week 11: Section 11.8 Power series Problems 5, 7, 8, 15. Section 11.9 Representations of functions as power series Problems 3, 5, 8.
  • Discussion Quiz 5 and solutions.
  • Week 12: Section 11.10 Taylor and Maclaurin series
  • Week 13: Section 10.1 Parametrization of curves Problem 6. 10.2 Calculus with parametric curves Problems 3,13,43.
  • Discussion Quiz 6 and solutions.
  • Week 14 (Last): Section 10.3 Polar coordinates Problems 55, 61. Section 10.4 Areas and arc length of polar curves Problem 7. Section 10.5 Conic sections Problems 25, 26, 27
